tourName: 23 day tour of China, Shanghai loop
generalInfo:
Start in Shanghai to go straight to Yangshuo, then follow our China backpacker trail all the way back to Shanghai. This includes most of the highlights of our full China backpacking tour, like the pandas in Chengdu, the Terracotta Warriors in Xi’an, and bamboo rafting in Yangshuo!

Included in all tours:

Epic Adventure Leaders, aka a local legends, to turn your trip into the adventure of a lifetime
All local transport within China
Accommodation (including hostels, 1-night camp on the Great Wall of China & a sleeper train) Please note: Your camping stay on the Great Wall is weather dependent. The alternative stay will be a cosy guesthouse nearby.
Meals provided: There are no meals included on this tour. Your Adventure Leader will be able to guide you to the best food spots!

Accommodation style:

In true backpacking style, our accommodation is in shared hostel rooms as standard on this tour. If you’d prefer a little extra comfort and your own space to relax after an action-packed day, room upgrades are available. Please request this on booking.

Included activities:

Bike & Bamboo Raft the Yulong River (Yangshuo)
Take a Yangtze River Cruise (Chongqing)
Discover Hongya Cave at Night (Chongqing)
Visit the Giant Panda Breeding Center (Chengdu)
Take a Mandarin Lesson with Your Adventure Leader (Chengdu, Dengfeng, Beijing & Shanghai)
Visit the Terracotta Warriors & Mausoleum of Qin Shi Huang (Xi’an)
Take a Kung Fu Lesson & Show at Shaolin Temple (Dengfeng)
Take an Evening Mandarin Lesson & Pubquiz (Dengfeng)
Hike & Camp on the Great Wall (Beijing) (Please note, due to cold weather before the end of April and after September 30th, we stay in a guest house near the Wall instead of camping).
Visit West Lake & Take a Boat Tour (Hangzhou)
Hike Jiuyao Mountain for Sunset (Hangzhou)
Hike the 9 Creeks in Misty Woods (Hangzhou)
Jinmao Tower Platform View (Shanghai)

dayInfo.description: Shanghai & Guilin: Meet your Adventure Leader and new travel crew for a pre-departure briefing, where you’ll get the lowdown on the epic journey ahead. It’s the perfect chance to start bonding with your group and get excited for what’s to come. After the briefing, head to Pudong Airport for your flight south to Guilin. On arrival, a private driver will be waiting to whisk you away to Yangshuo, where you’ll meet up with the rest of the crew who started their journey in Hong Kong. From here, the adventure across China really begins — new faces, stunning landscapes, and a trip packed with unforgettable moments.

Yangshuo: Your first full day in Yangshuo is all about choice — and there’s no wrong one! You could join a hands-on cooking class and learn to whip up classic Chinese dishes, or paddle along the Li River on a peaceful kayaking adventure surrounded by jaw-dropping karst peaks. Feeling curious about local wellness traditions? Try out hot cupping or another traditional therapy for a uniquely Chinese experience. Whether you go foodie, active or cultural, today is all about soaking up the rhythm of life in southern China — relaxed, scenic, and full of surprises.

Yangshuo: Start the morning off with a relaxing bike ride and cruise down the Yulong River on Chinese style gondolas. On your first afternoon in Yangshuo, you can take part in our optional activity - (Hop on the minibus to Moon Hill and visit the local mud baths, cave complex and hot springs). In the evening let your hair down enjoy some karaoke with your fellow travellers!

Yangshuo: Today you free to do what you want. But you can take part in some of our highly recommended optional activities - (Rock climb to the top of the regions limestone peaks or experience what life is like on a local farmland visit your Adventure Leader's home village).

Chongqing: Today we bid farewell to your Adventure Leader in Yangshuo and set off for the next leg of your journey — Chongqing, China’s mountain metropolis. Once you’ve checked in and dropped your bags, it’s time to hit the water for a Yangtze River cruise. Watch the skyline come alive as neon lights shimmer across the water — a truly spectacular way to see this city in all its nighttime glory. Afterwards, we’ll make our way to Hongya Cave, an eight-storey wonder of wooden balconies, glowing lanterns and buzzing food stalls perched above the river. Wander through its winding corridors, grab some street food or find a cosy spot for dinner with a view. It’s a feast for the senses and the perfect way to wrap up your first evening in Chongqing!

Chongqing: Kick off the morning with an optional visit to Liziba Station, where Chongqing’s monorail famously zips straight through a residential building — an engineering marvel that perfectly sums up this city’s wild, vertical personality. From there, dive into Chongqing’s fascinating past as you explore hidden air raid shelters, now transformed into creative underground spaces that reveal another side of the city. Next, stop by the grand People’s Great Hall, whose sweeping architecture reflects the city’s post-war ambition and pride. This afternoon, you can opt to explore Chaotianmen Dock, the dramatic meeting point of the Yangtze and Jialing Rivers, before winding your way up to Eling Park for panoramic views across the city’s layered skyline. As night falls, follow your Adventure Leader to the lively Guanyinqiao Area, where neon lights, bustling restaurants and vibrant bars set the scene for an unforgettable evening in China’s mountain metropolis.

Chengdu: This morning, wave goodbye to your Adventure Leader in Chongqing and board the train bound for Chengdu, the relaxed heart of Sichuan Province. Once you’ve arrived and settled into your accommodation, the rest of the day is yours to explore at your own pace. If you’re up for it, meet your new Adventure Leader for a gentle afternoon stroll through People’s Park, where locals sip jasmine tea, play mahjong, and practice tai chi beneath the shade of old trees. Then wander through the lively Kuanzhai Alley, a maze of restored courtyards filled with artisan shops, snack stalls and teahouses that perfectly capture Chengdu’s easygoing spirit. As the evening unfolds, grab dinner at one of the many nearby eateries — perhaps trying your first taste of the city’s legendary Sichuan spice!

Chengdu: Wake up early to go and visit the Chengdu Breeding & Research Center. Get up close and personal with pandas and learn about how the centre breed and release them into the wild. Here, you will have a Mandarin lesson with your Adventure Leader in the afternoon and in the evening you can take part in some of our suggested optional activity - (Go and experience the Sichuan opera and culture show - a one of a kind performance with acrobats, dancers, and puppets).

Chengdu: Today you free to do what you want. But, you can take part in some of our suggested optional activities - (Travel to Leshan and see the largest stone Buddha in the world (it’s 70m tall!) or have a try of the Sichuan Hot Pot, an authentic fiery Chinese speciality). In the evening take some time to kick back and enjoy a night out in Chengdu with your fellow crew!

Xian: Wave goodbye to your Adventure Leader in Chengdu and hop on the train to Xi’an, one of China’s most storied cities and the ancient starting point of the Silk Road. After checking in and settling into your accommodation, it’s time to get your first taste of the city’s rich history. You can opt to cycle along the Ming Dynasty City Walls, the best-preserved in all of China, for sweeping views of both old and new Xi’an. Or, dive straight into the city’s vibrant culture with a visit to the Bell and Drum Towers, before wandering through the Muslim Quarter, where centuries of Silk Road influences blend into a maze of lanterns, spices and sizzling street food. As night falls, tuck into Xi’an’s famous local snacks — from hand-pulled noodles to juicy lamb skewers — and browse the lively Silk Road night market for souvenirs, trinkets and a taste of the city’s timeless charm.

Xian: Wake up and travel to see the Terracotta Warriors, made up of life-size terra cotta sculptures in battle formations. In the evening you can take part in some optional activities - (Spend your evening watching the music and light fountain show in the Big Wild Goose Pagoda).

Shaolin: In the morning board a private minivan and then transfer to a bus to DengFeng. Once you arrive in Shaolin, it's time to take part in our next activity ~ Put your strength and flexibility to the test in a Kung Fu lesson and show at a local Kungfu Children's Home. For your evening meal, you will have dinner at your guesthouse and enjoy another Mandarin lesson - good luck/Yiqie` shu`nli`! Let's end the night with a pub quiz!

Today you’ve got two incredible options to choose from. You can journey to the legendary Shaolin Temple, the birthplace of Kung Fu and one of China’s most sacred sites. Wander through ancient courtyards where monks have trained for centuries, then hike up to Dharma Cave, a peaceful mountain spot for Buddhist pilgrims with breathtaking views across the valley below. Prefer a different kind of awe? Head instead to the Longmen Grottoes, a UNESCO World Heritage site home to thousands of intricate Buddha carvings etched into the cliffs along the Yi River — an unforgettable window into China’s spiritual past. This evening is free to relax, grab dinner at your own pace, and get a good night’s rest — you’ve got another big day of adventure ahead!

Beijing: Arrive at Beijing and transfer by minibus to your hostel. (You won’t be staying at this hostel, but will be able to use their facilities). You will then board a bus and make your way to The Great Wall in the afternoon. Hike on an unrestored part of the wall and enjoy the glorious views. As a group, you will eat dinner at a local farm and then begin your hike to an unrestored section of the wall, where we will have the place to ourselves! When you arrive you will set up camp and settle down to watch the sunset over the Wonders of the World before pitching up your tent for a night camping. (Please note, due to cold weather before the end of April and after September, we stay in a guest house near the Wall instead of camping but still return to the Wall to watch the sunrise in the morning).

Beijing: Wake up early for a once-in-a-lifetime moment — watching the sunrise over the Great Wall of China. As the first light spills across the ancient stones, take a deep breath and soak it all in — it’s a view you’ll never forget. (Weather dependent, but always worth the early start!) After returning to Beijing, the rest of the day is yours to explore at your own pace. You might choose to wander the creative 798 Art District, where modern galleries and street art fill converted factory spaces, or stroll the tranquil gardens of the Summer Palace, surrounded by willow-lined lakes and ornate bridges. Prefer to keep the group vibes going? Team up with your travel crew and discover more of the city’s treasures — from hidden hutong cafés to bustling local markets. However you spend it, today’s the perfect mix of freedom, culture, and unforgettable views.

Beijing: Begin the day with the option to cross Tiananmen Square, the heart of modern China, before stepping through the grand gates of the Forbidden City — the world’s largest palace complex. Once home to 24 emperors, its maze of courtyards, golden roofs, and hidden chambers is packed with centuries of intrigue and imperial history. For a panoramic finale, climb up Jingshan Park, a peaceful hill offering sweeping views over the palace rooftops and Beijing’s skyline beyond — the perfect photo spot. As evening falls, the choice is yours. You could catch an incredible Chinese acrobatics show, where balance, strength, and precision take centre stage, or feast on Beijing’s legendary Peking Roast Duck, a dish once reserved for royalty and now one of China’s most celebrated culinary experiences.

Beijing: Spend your final day in Beijing your way. You could browse the city’s bustling markets for souvenirs and quirky finds before visiting the nearby Temple of Heaven, where locals gather to play cards, practice tai chi, and sing in open-air choirs. Or, dive into Beijing’s cultural heart with a visit to the Nanluoguxiang district, one of the city’s best-preserved historical areas. Wander through the maze of hutongs and siheyuan courtyards, stopping at cosy cafés, boutique bars, and family-run craft shops along the way — the perfect blend of old and new Beijing. As evening falls, make your way to the station and board the night train to Hangzhou. Settle into your sleeper cabin and drift off as the lights of the capital fade behind you — the next chapter of your China adventure awaits.

Hangzhou: Arrive in Hangzhou and transfer by metro to the hostel for breakfast. Visit the famous West Lake and take a boat tour of one of the islands. In the afternoon you have the option to visit China's National Tea Museum, or Hangzhou Silk Museum or Lingyin Temple. This evening it is time to hike up to Jiuyao Mountain and see the sunset!

Hangzhou & Shanghai: Get up early and hike to the Nine Creeks, a trail hidden in the mountains in the West Lake Scenic Area of western Hangzhou city. After the hike, you will return to your hostel and check out and enjoy some lunch. In the afternoon hop on a train to Shanghai. When you arrive in Shanghai you will make your way to the Phoenix Hostel hostel via metro. In the evening, ask your Adventure Leader for suggestions for great food and drink.

Shanghai: Wake up ready for your next Mandarin lesson taught by professional teachers from a Chinese Language School. Later on in the day, you'll be able to take part in a variety of optional activities - (Walk to the Yu Gardens, a garden located beside the City God Temple, explore the People’s Square, head to Nanjing Road - the world's busiest shopping street or set off for the Shanghai Drunken Panda Pub Crawl).

Shanghai: Today is all yours to spend however you like! Feeling adventurous? Head to Disneyland and enjoy a full day of rides, shows, and magical moments. More into culture? Explore the treasures of the Shanghai Museum or wander Moganshan Art Street to soak up the city’s creative side. If you’re craving a change of pace, take a trip out to Zhujiajiao Watertown, where canals, bridges, and historic architecture create a peaceful escape. Or, put your bargaining skills to the test at Shanghai’s famous fake goods market. However you spend it, today is all about enjoying Shanghai your way — a chance to explore, relax, and make the city your own.

Shanghai: Today, wander the leafy streets of the French Concession, where charming architecture meets hidden cafés, boutique shops, and quiet corners perfect for photos. Pop into a secret propaganda museum for a quirky slice of history, then lose yourself in the arty lanes of Tianzifang, full of galleries, craft shops, and vibrant street life. Next, venture into Shanghai’s ultra-modern financial district and head up Jinmao Tower for sweeping city views from the observation deck. Feeling brave? Step out onto the skywalk, 340 metres above the streets below, for a thrill you won’t forget! As evening falls, your Adventure Leader will point you to the best local spots for dinner and drinks, whether you’re after street eats, stylish bars, or a memorable night out in the city.
Shanghai: After, you will take the time to say goodbye to your fellow travellers and either head home or continue your travels!

tourName: Altai Mountains overland adventure, 28 days
generalInfo: While more in the spirit of Fitzroy McLean than in his footsteps, this exploratory journey will take you to the very heart of Central Asia; the remote  borderlands of Mongolia, China & Kazakhstan.

dayInfo.title: Ulaanbaatar.
dayInfo.description: Welcome to Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. In the evening of Day 1 you join your Leader, Simon Maddison and fellow travellers at 5:00pm for your Welcome Meeting, a walk around the city and dinner.

dayInfo.title: Terelj National Park.
dayInfo.description: This morning, we’ll set off to explore Terelj National Park, a stunning landscape of granite formations, pine forests, and open meadows. Visit Turtle Rock, one of Mongolia’s most famous natural landmarks, and hike up to the Ariyabal Meditation Temple, perched on a hillside with sweeping valley views. Enjoy a home-hosted lunch with a local Kazakh family and learn about their daily life and traditions. On our return to the city, we’ll stop at the Genghis Khan Equestrian Statue — a 40-meter-tall stainless steel monument, the largest of its kind in the world.

dayInfo.title: To Turgen Mountains.
dayInfo.description: This morning we fly to Ulaangom. Upon arrival we enjoy lunch with a local throat singer’s family, offering a unique cultural experience. After lunch, we drive to the Turgen Mountains, home to the tallest peaks in Uvs Province. Enjoy a scenic hike through the area before dinner and overnight at a traditional ger camp.

dayInfo.title: Achit Lake.
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, travel to the spectacular Achit Lake, the largest freshwater lake in the Uvs and Bayan-Ölgii regions. This pristine lake is known for its dramatic sunsets and rich wildlife — from fish species like Mongolian grayling to migratory birds such as geese and ducks. Achit Lake and its surroundings are part of a protected Ramsar wetland area, home to over 150 bird species. Tonight, stay with a welcoming Bayad host family, one of Mongolia’s ancient ethnic groups known for their deep historical roots and warm hospitality.

dayInfo.title: To Tolbo Lake.
dayInfo.description: Drive to Tolbo Lake, stopping in Ulgii town for lunch and to stock up on supplies. This evening, enjoy dinner and rest at your Ger camp beside the lake’s tranquil shores.

dayInfo.title: Eagle Hunters.
dayInfo.description: Today, immerse yourself in the ancient Kazakh tradition of eagle hunting. Visit a local eagle hunter’s family and learn about the deep bond between hunter and bird. You’ll gain insight into the care, training, and cultural significance of this centuries-old practice — and even try handling themajestic eagle yourself!

dayInfo.title: Life of the Eagle Hunter.
dayInfo.description: Spend another full day with your eagle hunter hosts — a rare opportunity to further explore this living heritage. Take part in daily routines, storytelling, and perhaps a short hunt demonstration, depending on the season and conditions.

dayInfo.title: To Zereg Sum.
dayInfo.description: Travel to Zereg Sum, enjoying a scenic stop for lunch by Khar Us Lake. Upon arrival, meet a local camel herder family and learn about nomadic life in the desert steppe. Prepare with your hosts for tomorrow’s migration journey.

dayInfo.title: Camel Migration.
dayInfo.description: Join your host family for a full-day camel migration, traveling alongside the herders as they move their camp and livestock — a rare glimpse into Mongolia’s nomadic traditions in action. In the evening, transfer to a local hotel to rest.

dayInfo.title: Bodonchiin Gorge.
dayInfo.description: Drive to Bulgan Sum, near the Mongolian–Chinese border. En route, visit Bodonchiin Gorge, home to the remarkable Yamaan Us petroglyphs — ancient rock carvings protected as a national cultural monument. Enjoy a picnic lunch surrounded by stunning scenery before continuing to your hotel.

dayInfo.title: To Qinghe.
dayInfo.description: Today we cross the border to China at Takashiken Port and drive to Qinghe. In the afternoon we visit Sandaohaizi Huge Rocks and marvel at these ancient geological formations.

dayInfo.title: To Keketuohai National Park.
dayInfo.description: Today we drive from Qinghe to Keketuohai Scenic Area. We can enjoy hiking the Ertix River valley with a 2-hour guided walk along the trail. Whilst in the Keketuohai National Park we will see the Irtysh Grand Canyon and the No. 3 Pit a treasure bowl of 84 rare minerals such as lithium, beryllium, tantalum, niobium and cesium. We continue to Fuyun County for overnight.

dayInfo.title: To Burqin.
dayInfo.description: Morning transfer to Burqin County. We will spend some time watching the vast array of birds at Wulungu lake. In the afternoon, we visit Wucaitan Scenic Area to view the Danxia formations and the Irtysh River at sunset. Overnight in Burqin County.

dayInfo.title: To Hemu.
dayInfo.description: Today we transfer to Hemu Village which is set in a particularly scenic area. We spend an afternoon at leisure giving time to visit Hemu Bridge and to explore the village.

dayInfo.title: To Kanas Lake.
dayInfo.description: Early morning sunrise viewing at Hemu. Transfer to Kanas Lake. Visit Kanas Scenic Area by bus, with an optional boat trip or visit to the fish-watching Pavilion. Overnight near Kanas Scenic Area.

dayInfo.title: Jimunai.
dayInfo.description: Morning visit to Shenxian Bay, Moon Bay, and Wolong Bay. After lunch visit to the Tuost Grassland. Afternoon transfer via Burqin to Jimunai County. Evening at leisure in Jimunai.

dayInfo.title: Jimunai.
dayInfo.description: Today we explore further in the Jimunai Grassland Stone City region. In the morning we visit to Sarwuleng Village. Afternoon optional visits to Jimunai Port or Songhai Bay, time permitting.

dayInfo.title: To Lake Markakol.
dayInfo.description: We depart from China and cross the border to Kazakhstan. We transfer along the historic Austrian Road (built 1915–1916) to Urunhayka village on Lake Markakol — a remote alpine lake known for pristine nature and mixed ethnic culture. In the afternoon we will take a short walk along the lake.

dayInfo.title: To Uryl.
dayInfo.description: today we take a scenic drive through the Katon-Karagai area to Uryl village. The route passes untouched mountain landscapes far from civilization.

dayInfo.title: Lake Yazevoe.
dayInfo.description: We take a day trip to Lake Yazevoe, a small mountain lake famous for fishing where we will see clear reflections of Belukha Mountain, and a cascade of 10 waterfalls. In the evening we will enjoy dinner in a Kazakh village with an introduction to local traditions, lifestyle, crafts, food, and music.

dayInfo.title: Valley of Kings.
dayInfo.description: Today we make an excursion to the Berel Museum-Reserve an archaeological site with Scythian royal tombs preserved in permafrost, also known as the “Valley of Kings.”

dayInfo.title: Lake Rakhmanovskoye.
dayInfo.description: Today we drive to Rakhmanovskie Klyuchi hot and cold mineral springs surrounded by cedar forest. Scenic stops include a viewpoint of Belukha Mountain and a boat trip across Rakhmanov Lake to Arasanka mouth and Veranica Spit waterfall.

dayInfo.title: To Sibiny Lakes.
dayInfo.description: Transfer to the Sibiny Lakes area, surrounded by granite mountains and famous for clear waters and rock formations. Visit Ablaykit — ruins of a 17th-century Buddhist monastery.

dayInfo.title: To Ust-Kamenogorsk.
dayInfo.description: Transfer to Ust-Kamenogorsk (Oskemen) via scenic mountain roads. Free evening in the city.

dayInfo.title: Ust-Kamenogorsk and to Almaty.
dayInfo.description: Today we enjoy sightseeing in Ust-Kamenogorsk before boarding out evening train to Almaty.

dayInfo.title: On board to Almaty.
dayInfo.description: We track across the plains drawing closer to Almaty.

dayInfo.title: Almaty.
dayInfo.description: We arrive just as the day begins so after some time to relax we will enjoy some afternoon Almaty sightseeing before gathering for a farewell dinner to reflect on our journey.

dayInfo.title: Almaty.
dayInfo.description: Our journey ends after breakfast.

tourName: Beijing to Shanghai family holiday, 13 days
generalInfo:
Discover China beyond the postcards on this immersive 13-day family journey through four iconic cities. Designed for curious learners of all ages, this tour blends language practice, cultural workshops, and authentic local interactions.
Begin in Beijing, where you’ll explore the Forbidden City and hike the quieter Mutianyu section of the Great Wall. Dive deeper with a hands-on dumpling-making session in a local home and a rickshaw ride through historic hutongs, guided by residents who share stories of daily life.

Travel by high-speed rail to Xi’an, cradle of Chinese civilization. Marvel at the Terracotta Warriors, then craft your own miniature replica in a local artisan’s studio. Wander the bustling Muslim Quarter, sampling Hui cuisine, and visit a traditional cave-dwelling household to learn about rural Shaanxi heritage.
In Chengdu, meet giant pandas at Dujiangyan Panda Valley—a conservation-focused facility supporting breeding and habitat restoration. Sip tea in People’s Park like a true Chengdu local, try Sichuan cooking in a family kitchen, and stroll Jinli Ancient Street for safe, flavorful street food.

The journey ends in Shanghai, where modernity meets memory. Share lunch at a community-run canteen serving elderly residents, explore a neighborhood history museum preserving grassroots stories, and enjoy a warm conversation over tea in the home of a retired Shanghainese—offering rare insight into urban life across generations.

Throughout, friendly local guides weave simple Mandarin phrases into daily activities, turning every meal, market visit, and walk into a gentle language lesson. Accommodations are comfortable, locally owned hotels, and intercity travel uses China’s efficient high-speed rail network to reduce carbon impact.
More than a tour, this is a bridge—to people, language, and the living culture of China. Perfect for families seeking meaningful connection, not just sightseeing.

dayInfo.description: Beijing Arrival. Your guide will accompany you to your centrally-located hotel in a comfortable private vehicle and help you with check-in. Meals: None

Beijing Highlights. Let's start our Chinese immersion tour with the Temple of Confucius, to begin to understand how Confucius's principles shaped Chinese tradition and beliefs. Then we'll head to the Imperial Academy and visit the Lama Temple. Enjoy the famous Peking roast duck for lunch. Kids can talk to the waitress in mandarin and order food from a Chinese menu. Walk into a traditional courtyard and visit a hutong family. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Beijing. Discover the Summer Palace and its beautiful architecture and vast gardens in the morning. Lunch will be arranged in a hidden retreat-restaurant at the foot of the Great Wall. Drive to China's amazing icon, the Great Wall. We recommend the Mutianyu section for its majestic views and comparatively smaller crowds. A chairlift going up and toboggan sliding down are included, to help make the experience more fun for kids. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Beijing. Today we'll explore the highlights of Beijing city using public transport. Kids will learn how to ask for directions and will read some Chinese signs along the way. First visit Tian'anmen Square, and then the Forbidden City. Enjoy the famous Peking roast duck for lunch, and then learn the art of Chinese calligraphy from a hutong family. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Beijing to Xi’an. Head to the Temple of Heaven, the place where emperors worshipped heaven. Have a tai chi class with a renowned local tai chi master. You will learn some basic movements and how these relate to Chinese culture and traditional health science. Take the bullet train to Xi'an in the afternoon. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Xi’an. The Terracotta Warriors are one of the greatest man-made wonders. We will introduce you to a different Terracotta Museum, one that can't be googled. Then pay a visit to a local cave dwelling where a craftsman makes warriors in the traditional way. Make a little warrior of your own, with your local host's help. After lunch, we visit the ancient City Wall of Xi'an and enjoy a bike ride on it. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Xi’an. The Xian Museum show you the development of thirteen ancient capitals in the past dynasties. Then learn the traditional architecture at the Small Wild Goose Pagoda. Visit an energetic local family. Learn how to make dumplings and enjoy a family meal with them. Have a calligraphy class in the Intangible Cultural Heritage Museum. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Xi'an to Chengdu. Take a bullet train to Chengdu in the morning. Spend your afternoon in People's Park. The park is a lovely place for a leisurely walk or to observe locals engaging in various activities like tai chi or traditional music performances. Have a cup of tea in tea house is a traditional custom for Chengdu people. Tasting local street food at Jinli Street. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Chengdu. Drive for 2 hours and arrive in Leshan by noon. After a short break and lunch, your journey to the Giant Buddha begins. Climb up the Buddha, then walk down the narrow plank all the way to its feet, to discover you are only as tall as one of its toes. A cruise on the river nearby is also included, so you can have a different panoramic view of the Buddha Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Chengdu to Shanghai. The Dujiangyan Panda Valley, nestled among mountains and waters, provides fresh air and a serene atmosphere with fewer visitors. Your lunch is an authentic Sichuan hot pot, known for its bold flavors, particularly the numbing heat from Sichuan peppercorns. After lunch, you visit a Chinese painting studio, where a professional painter guides you in creating your own panda artwork to take home. After the tour, your private guide and driver will accompany you to the airport and you will fly to Shanghai. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Shanghai. Follow your guide to discover the secret of Shanghai's rise to prominence. This morning, we'll explore the modern residential areas and local life in Cao Yang New Neighborhood. Visit local markets to sample fresh produce and snacks while practicing your language skills. Experience a public ferry and then ascend the tallest building in Shanghai — Shanghai Tower. Last stop is the Bund, where you will explore diverse architectural styles and enjoy breathtaking views of the modern skyline. Meals: Breakfast, Lunch

Shanghai. Let's create some memorable family moments at Shanghai Disneyland. A private vehicle will escort you directly to the Disneyland entrance. Enjoy fun experiences the whole day, and fireworks in the evening. Meal: Breakfast
Shanghai departure. Your private car, driver, and guide will be ready and waiting at your hotel lobby to get you to the airport on time. Have a nice journey home!

tourName: Beijing to Shanghai tour in China
placesVisited: Beijing, the Great Wall trekking between the Gubeikou section and the Jinshanling section, Xi’an, Terracotta Warriors, Shanghai, Huangshan National Park trek, picturesque Huizhou region and villages
generalInfo:
Discover the ancient sights and modern delights of China’s north on this 12-day adventure. Journey from Beijing to Shanghai and travel through the ancient city of Xi’an, to the heights of Huangshan, the base of the Great Wall and deep into the Huizhou countryside. Encounter friendly people, bustling markets and amazing historical landmarks as you take in the crazy contrasts and profound experiences that render China such a remarkable country.

This is a small group guided trip with journeys on two sleeper trains, to help maximise your time in your destinations, while also giving you a chance to interact with locals and see some beautiful countryside. You will also travel by public and private bus, high speed train, subway and taxi. To keep initial costs down, no meals are included, giving you freedom to decide where and what you eat.

There is a lot packed into a short amount of time on this exciting trip, with highlights including an overnight stay at a family run guesthouse at the Great Wall, seeing the thousands of Terracotta Warriors, exploring the idyllic Huizhou countryside and villages on foot or by bike and discovering the mountain heights of Huangshan, where the stunning rock pinnacles of the Yellow Mountain peek through atmospheric mists.

dayInfo.title: Beijing.
dayInfo.description: Nimen Hao! Welcome to China. The capital of the most populous country on earth, Beijing is a food-centric city with ancient sites and modern architecture around every corner. Your adventure begins with an important welcome meeting at 6 pm this evening. Following the meeting, settle into your hotel and then perhaps get together with your newfound travel crew and head out for dinner – your local leader will have a couple of recommendations.

dayInfo.title: Great Wall.
dayInfo.description: Enjoy a few hours of free time in the morning to explore Beijing before taking a 3-hour private bus to a section of the original Great Wall– the Gubeikou section. Built as a northern defensive line for Beijing (then called Youzhou), this section of the Great Wall was first constructed between AD550 and AD557, then fortified during the early years of the Ming Dynasty. You’ll spend the night in a family-run guesthouse nearby, and while the facilities are more basic than some of the other accommodation on this trip, the homegrown hospitality more than makes up for it. Most travellers tonight choose to eat at the guesthouse for dinner as it's a great chance to sample local produce and delicious home cooking.

dayInfo.title: Great Wall.
dayInfo.description: Embrace an early start and make the trek from the Gubeikou section of the Great Wall to the Jinshanling section. Hike over steep, remote terrain for around 5–6 hours, taking in incredible views along this comparatively quiet trail. Some parts of the wall are unrestored, so you'll need to concentrate hard to keep your footing, while other stretches will take you off the wall to walk alongside it through the countryside. The trek will be challenging, but the sight of the wall snaking through the hills as far as the eye can see and the feeling of being immersed in ancient history will be ample reward for your efforts. After the hike, return to the guesthouse, put your feet up, have a few beers or maybe learn how to play mahjong with the locals.

dayInfo.title: Beijing - Overnight Train.
dayInfo.description: Take a 3-hour drive back to Beijing before midday and make use of your last free afternoon in the capital. Consider checking out the Temple of Heaven while you're in the city, or tuck into a Peking Duck banquet right in its birthplace. Keep in mind that this evening you’ll board a 13-hour overnight train bound for Xi’an, so maybe stock up on snacks and supplies for the journey. While comfortable, the train isn’t luxurious, but it's certainly one of the best ways to come face to face with the vastness of this country. Be sure to have a good book or a device loaded with binge-worthy shows for the journey.

dayInfo.title: Xi'an.
dayInfo.description: Welcome to Xi’an – the capital of Shaanxi Province and the largest city in northwest China. Head to the hotel to leave your luggage. Then make the 2-hour journey by public transport to the acclaimed Terracotta Warriors. Spend a few hours at this incredible archaeological find, buried for 2000 years before being discovered in 1974 by farmers digging a well. These clay statues of soldiers, horses and chariots were commissioned by the Emperor Qin Shi Huang as part of his mausoleum after he ascended to the throne in 264 BC. Three main pits are open for viewing, where just under 2000 of the total 6000 warriors – each an individual with a different costume, height, and even facial expression – are on display. Return to Xi'an in the late afternoon, check into your hotel and enjoy a relaxing evening. Xi’an’s Silk Road history means it has an exciting mixture of cultures, especially found in its food options. Why not try one of the many food specialties in Xi'an for dinner? Your leader will be able to advise on some of the best to try.

dayInfo.title: Xi'an – Overnight Train.
dayInfo.description: This morning, head on a leader-led walking tour to the Muslim Quarter, which features narrow streets of quaint shops, lively food markets, and the life of Chinese Muslims. Then enjoy some free time until your evening train. You can choose to visit the Bell Tower, which according to legend was built to restrain dragons that were causing earthquakes, or the Drum Tower, which is full of instruments once used to mark time and warn the population in emergencies after the walking tour. Another option is to explore the 13-kilometre-long City Walls and attached Gates where you can rent a bike on top and cycle the whole circle of the City Wall. In the evening, board your second overnight train bound for Shanghai (approximately 16 hours).

dayInfo.title: Shanghai.
dayInfo.description: Blending 21st-century architecture with old-world character, Shanghai pulses with the beat of contemporary China. Arrive and take the busy subway to your accommodation. Enjoy a full day of exploration, but don't worry if you can't see everything you want to today – you’ll be back later on in your trip. Get a taste of the city during the roaring 1920s with a leader-led walk of the Bund, a strip of spectacular art deco-style buildings. Wander the narrow winding lanes (nongtangs) of Old Shanghai, where you can get a glimpse of local life. Explore the European-influenced French Concession, then pound the pavement along Luwan's Huaihai Road – a busy shopping street. The area's tree-lined avenues and many Tudor mansions earned it the nickname 'Paris of the East'. When night falls, why not get together with a few of your travel pals for a taste of Shanghai’s eclectic food scene.

dayInfo.title: Huangshan.
dayInfo.description: Travel into stunning countryside by bullet train to Huangshan, otherwise known as Yellow Mountain. The 72 sharp peaks of Huangshan provide some of China's most breathtaking scenery, as well as a respite from the bustle of the city. Spend the next two days in a guesthouse with free time to explore the area as you wish. Two popular trails are the Eastern Steps (7.5 kilometres, approximately 3–4 hours) and the Western Steps (15 kilometres). It’s recommended to take the cable car to the summit, explore the area and then descend via the Western Steps. Whatever you choose, the dramatic limestone peaks framing this region make for some breathtaking vistas. After taking in the natural beauty of Huangshan during the day, return to the guesthouse for a well-earned evening rest.

dayInfo.title: Hongcun.
dayInfo.description: Jump on public bus again and travel to the picturesque villages of the Huizhou region (approximately 2 hours). A number of these villages are now World Heritage listed, and you may recognise the ramshackle, ornate buildings from the film ‘Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon’. Arrive in Hongcun, check-in to your village guesthouse and then set out on a guided tour by your leader of cobbled alleys and Ming Dynasty architecture. Following this short walk, you have the rest of the afternoon and evening free to spend as you wish. Perhaps you might like to clamber up into the hillsides for panoramic views over the traditional settlements. Or maybe you'd prefer to explore the surrounding villages on two wheels. Your group leader will have all the information on bicycle hire and other optional activities.

dayInfo.title: Shanghai.
dayInfo.description: Bid farewell to the glorious countryside and make the 3-hour journey back to Shanghai by bullet train. You’ll arrive back mid-afternoon, and if there’s time, consider booking into a traditional tea ceremony to learn how important this drink is to Chinese culture. Tonight is cause for celebration, so why not gather with your travel crew and go all out in one of Shanghai’s great restaurants. If you haven't already, tonight is the perfect chance to try the city's famous xiao long bao (steamed soup dumplings).

dayInfo.title: Shanghai.
dayInfo.description: With no activities planned for today, you are free to leave the accommodation at any time, provided you comply with your accommodation’s internal check-out policies. That doesn’t mean your adventure has to stop here! If you’d like to spend more time in Shanghai, we’ll be happy to organise additional accommodation (subject to availability).

tourName: Bejing to Lhasa tour, by train
generalInfo:
Beijing serves as the premier gateway for international travelers entering China. An optimal schedule involves dedicating two days to explore Beijing and an additional day in Xian. This arrangement ensures an immersive encounter with renowned attractions, including the majestic Great Wall, the imperial Forbidden City, and the captivating Terracotta Warriors and Horses of Xian.

During this journey, a truly unforgettable experience awaits as you traverse the remarkable Qinghai-Tibet railway. Subsequently, you will embark on the iconic 8-Day Lhasa and Everest Base Camp Tour. Accompanied by the illustrious presence of palaces, temples, and monasteries, this adventure grants you the privilege of relishing the breathtaking vistas of Tibet's revered Mount Everest, a veritable masterpiece of nature.

dayInfo.description: Beijing arrival || You will be picked up from the airport to your hotel in Beijing.
Beijing Day Tour || You will first visit the Forbidden City (4-Hour in-depth tour), and Beihai Royal Garden. (Having a hutong rickshaw tour to explore the old Beijinger’s life is optional)
Beijing Day Tour || Today you will visit the majestic Mutianyu Great Wall in Beijing. In the evening, board an overnight train to Xian.

Xian Day Tour || In the morning, you will be picked up at the train station and then start to visit the Eighth Wonder of the World - the Terracotta Warriors and Horses, which reflect the highly advanced technology in weapon-making 2,200 years ago.

Xian train to Lhasa on the Qinghai-Tibet Railway || In the morning, you will board the famous sky train to Lhasa and start the wonderful journey of exploring the highest railway in the world. The train journey will take you about 30 hours.

Lhasa Arrival || A full day window sightseeing along Qinghai-Tibet Railway, you will see land of snows, desert, immense grassland, ice mountain, beautiful lakes which will fairly entertaining. In the afternoon, you will be warmly received by your tour guide who would say Tashi Delek, which means wishing you all the best and transferred to your reserved hotel in Lhasa. Then have a good rest to acclimatize the high altitude in Lhasa.
Lhasa free day || The day is free day for you to acclimate to the altitude.

Lhasa City Tour || In the morning, you are going to visit Drepung monastery which is one of the “great three” Gelug monasteries of Tibet, founded in 1416 by Jamyang choge, one of the Tsongkhapa’s main disciples. Ganden palace used to be Dalai lama’s palace in the Drepung before he moved to the Potala palace. In the Afternoon, Tourists will visit Sera Monastery which is another one of the “great three” Gelug monasteries of Tibet, founded in 1419 by Jamchen Chojey, one of the Tsongkhapa’s main disciples. The hot attraction is the Monks debate at around 3 - 5 in the afternoon.

Lhasa City Tour || Firstly, Potala Palace is today’s first attraction, which is the residence of the past Dalai lama. The most valuable collections of Potala Palace are the gilded burial stupas of former Dalai Lamasand tremendous number of Buddhist frescoes, thangkas, combinations of mandala, figures of the Buddha. Then after lunch, tourists head to Jokhang Temple and Barkor Street surrounding. Inside you can see the statue of Buddha Sakyamuni at the age of twelve, perhaps the only most venerated object in Tibetan Buddhism.

Lhasa to Shigatse || In the morning, drive from Lhasa to Shigatse .On the way, drive over the Gampala pass (4790 m), and you will have a glimpse of Yamdrok-tso (4400m) .The Lake is surrounded by many snow-capped mountains and in the distance you can have spectacular views of Holy Mount Nyenchen Khangsar, (7191m) the highest mountain near Lhasa . Later, we will pass and enjoy the Korola Glacier on the roadside; At Manak Dam Lake, you can hang pray flag at Simila Mountain Pass; Then, we will arrive in Gyantse, historically Tibet's third largest city (after Lhasa and Shigatse). After one and a half driving, we arrive in Shigatse, which is the second largest city in Tibet. In Shigatse, we may visit traditional Barley Mill and view the landscape of Barley Field (in summer).

Shigatse to EBC via Tingri || After breakfast in hotel, you will drive to to Tingri from Shigatse. There is only 2-3hours driving from Tingri to Rongpuk through 90km new winding road in the mountains. On the way from Tingri to E.B.C, you can enjoy the stunning mountain scenery; pass the wild grassland, the torrent and soaring mountains. If it is in clear weather, you can see the panorama of Himalaya range and among mountains you can see 4 mountains which are 8000m high and more to enjoy like Mt. Lhotse (8516m), Mt. Everest (8848m), Mt. Qowowuyag (8201m) and Mt Mayalu (8463m), and even majestic view of golden summit of Mt. Everest at sunset. Stay overnight in Ronguk Guest House or local Tibetan Tent.

EBC – Gyirong || n the morning, you can appreciate the sunrise of Everest Peak if weather permits at the lodging area and then visit the Rongbuk Monstery - the unique highest monastery with nuns and monks living together. Later, we can visit the Everest Base Camp and take pictures of Mt. Everest at the closes distance in EBC. After that, we can drive from EBC to Kyirong border. On the way, tourists can enjoy breathtakign vista of Mt. Shishapangma and the Pekutso Lake. After passing the Ghungtang Lhamo(5236M), we will arrive in Kyirong in late afternoon.
Border Departure || Our Tibetan guide will assist you to exit China via the Gyirong border or Zhangmu border. Then you will take the transfer car to Kathmandu.

tourName: Bishkek to Beijing overland holiday
generalInfo: Join this Overland Expedition and venture off the tourist trail throughout Kyrgyzstan and follow the ancient trading routes along the Silk Road to Beijing. Discover stunning scenery and some of the oldest cities in the world steeped in history and legend from Lake IssyKul to Xi'an and its Terracotta Warriors. We travel on one of our overland trucks in Kyrgyzstan and then by trains and buses through China

tourName: China 10 day premium small group tour
generalInfo:
Experience China in style with our China Premium Tour, beginning in Beijing and culminating in Shanghai. Along the way, you'll discover iconic landmarks and immerse yourself in local culture like never before!

Whether you're hiking the Great Wall of China or cycling the city walls of Xi'an, indulging in Peking duck in Beijing or savoring beef in Pingyao, our China Premium Tour offers something for everyone. Immerse yourself in historic ancient towns and vibrant modern cities, explore rivers, temples, and bustling city streets. From the awe-inspiring Terracotta Warriors to the towering Jinmao Tower, this tour provides a thrilling glimpse into the diverse and captivating experiences China has to offer.

Accommodation:

Premium hotel accommodation throughout your tour
Local transport:
All transport within China, including bullet trains

Check out our included activities for this group tour below:

Walking tour (Beijing)
Welcome dinner (Beijing)
Day trip/hike on the Great Wall of China (Beijing)
Temple of Heaven visit (Beijing)
Pingyao Old Town entry ticket – options for exploring are traveller’s own (Pingyao)
Cycling the Old City walls (Xi’an)
Walking tour in the Muslim Quarter (Xi’an)
Day trip to the Terracotta Warriors (Shanghai)
Walking tour, including visits to Jinmao Tower, Yu Gardens (Shanghai)
Day trip to Zhujiajiao Water Town (Shanghai)
Huangpu River Cruise (Shanghai)
Farewell dinner (Shanghai)

dayInfo.description: Welcome to China: Your China Premium Tour begins today in Beijing. This afternoon, you'll meet your group and Adventure Leader in the hotel lobby. Your Adventure Leader will then take you on an orientation walk around the city, culminating in a delicious welcome dinner at a local restaurant, where you'll get to sample Beijing's best dish: Beijing duck! During dinner, you'll receive a detailed briefing about the exciting itinerary for the next 10 days. Afterward, you can either head back to the hotel to rest up for the next day's adventures or join your Adventure Leader at a local craft beer bar. The choice is yours!

Beijing: You'll start your day bright and early with breakfast provided by your Adventure Leader. Then, it's time to dive into the beauty and history of Beijing. Your first stops will be Tiananmen Square and the Forbidden City, followed by a hike up to Jingshan Park for breathtaking views of the city. In the afternoon, enjoy some free time exploring Nanluoguxiang, a vibrant area known for its fantastic shopping and picturesque lake. There are plenty of great restaurants for lunch, or if you're interested in something different, take the metro to see the Bird’s Nest, the iconic stadium from the 2008 Summer and 2022 Winter Olympics. The evening is yours to enjoy as you wish. Don't forget to ask your Adventure Leader for recommendations on the best spots for cocktails in the city!

The Great Wall: Today, you're in for another early start as you head out to one of the wonders of the world – the Great Wall of China. After breakfast, you'll travel a couple of hours outside the capital to a section of the wall, where you'll spend the day hiking and taking in the incredible views. You'll return to the city in the late afternoon. From there, you can either rest up or continue exploring. If you have the energy, consider visiting the Summer Palace or District 798 for some more adventures. The choice is yours!

Beijing/Pingyao: This morning, you'll start the day by exploring the Temple of Heaven. Situated in a vast park in the city center, it’s a popular spot for locals to exercise. Join them for a tai chi class to get into the spirit of local life! After an early lunch at the Fake Market, you'll have some time for shopping. Be sure to stock up on snacks before we move on to our next destination on the China Premium Tour: Pingyao! You'll take a bullet train for just over three hours, arriving in Pingyao in time for an optional group dinner at a local restaurant. Make sure to try the Pingyao beef! If you still have energy left, spend the evening exploring the lively town, filled with bars and markets.

Pingyao/Xi’an: After enjoying breakfast at your hotel this morning, you'll have a free day to explore Pingyao's Old Town. With its rich history, the town boasts over twenty museums, temples, and other highlights—all accessible with your provided entry ticket. You might want to visit the first Bank of China, explore the Temple of Confucius, or take a hike along the city walls. In the evening, you'll board the bullet train to your next destination: Xi'an! You'll arrive tonight, just in time to get a good night's sleep ahead of another busy day.

Xi’an: Your Adventure Leader will guide you to a local spot for breakfast – make sure to eat well, because today’s activity is an energetic one! Xi’an is world-renowned for its stunning city walls, and this morning you’ll cycle 13km along them, enjoying breathtaking views across the old capital. After a stop for lunch, you can opt to join your group for another exciting cultural activity: a calligraphy class at the Small Goose Pagoda. Here, you’ll learn about Chinese calligraphy and try your hand at it. In the evening, your Adventure Leader will take you on a fascinating walking tour through Xi’an’s Muslim Quarter. You’ll see landmarks like the Drum and Bell Tower and get the chance to try some tasty regional snacks. Feeling comfortable with your group yet? Great – join them for karaoke tonight!

Xi’an/Shanghai: Following an early breakfast, you'll head to one of Xi’an’s – and indeed, China’s – most iconic archaeological sites: the Terracotta Warriors! This UNESCO World Heritage Site houses the tomb of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of Imperial China (259-210 BC), guarded by thousands of life-sized terracotta statues. You'll conclude your tour with a visit to the local museum and cinema, where a documentary will provide all the details about this remarkable site. From there, it’s off to the train station to transfer to Shanghai – the final destination on your China Premium Tour! You'll arrive later in the evening, just in time to rest up for another exciting day tomorrow.

Shanghai: Grab breakfast at your hotel this morning, but save some space before setting off on a walking tour of fascinating Shanghai. Your Adventure Leader will offer insights into the lives of the locals, and along the way, you'll get to try a couple of local dishes like stuffed pancakes and sesame bread. You’ll visit highlights such as the Jinmao Tower, the Financial District, and the Yu Gardens, before having some free time to shop and grab lunch in the local area. Are you a daredevil? If heights are your thing, you can opt for the Skywalk in Jinmao Tower! Strap yourself in and step outside the tower to see the city from 350 meters up in the air! Once back on the ground, the afternoon is yours to spend as you see fit. You might want to continue exploring the city on foot, visit the Museum of Contemporary Art, or wander the shopper’s paradise of Nanjing Road! In the evening, you can opt to join your group for a cooking class, where you’ll learn to make your dinner. On the menu: xiaolongbao!

Shanghai: Following breakfast, you're off on an exciting day trip just outside Shanghai to the ancient water town of Zhujiajiao! Known for its network of rivers and canals that weave between historic buildings, Zhujiajiao is over 1,500 years old, with archaeological findings dating back over 5,000 years. On your tour, you'll explore old trade houses, take a local boat trip, and learn about the Great Canal of China, which links Hangzhou and Beijing. Returning to Shanghai in the late afternoon, you'll continue your aquatic adventure with a stylish boat cruise down the Huangpu River. Spend your last evening with your group in style, enjoying a glass of fizz and some snacks while watching the sunset from the river. Afterward, head for a farewell dinner to celebrate an amazing trip. If you’d like, you can also head into the city for cocktails at one of the many rooftop bars.

Farewell China: After breakfast this morning, your China Premium Tour comes to an end. If you need a train back to Beijing or a transfer to the airport, please contact us and we'll be happy to assist. Safe travels!

tourName: China 8 day tour
placesVisited: Beijing, Xi’an, Great Wall of China, Terracotta Army, Shanghai, Sleeper train journey, Internal flight Xi’an to Shanghai
generalInfo:
Beijing - Great Wall of China - Terracotta Army - Shanghai

This China tour is a nine day, tailor made trip for those who like to travel independently but follow a carefully crafted itinerary, with transport, accommodation and excursions taken care of. In just eight days you will city hop the highlights of China from the bright lights of Beijing and the Great Wall of China, to the amazing terracotta army and finally sensational Shanghai, where an explosion of modernity coexists with the rich Chinese history.

Starting in Beijing, we recommend three days here to adjust to the buzz of this mega metropolis, and navigate your way around its narrow streets or ‘hutongs’ and yet find time to soak up the tranquillity of some of its more sacred sites, such as The Temple of Heavenly Peace. Make sure that you set aside ample time to explore the mammoth and amazing Forbidden City, complete with thousands of palaces, museums and pavilions that were home to Chinese emperors over many generations.

Another attraction of epic proportions is the Great Wall of China beginning in Beijing, before taking an overnight sleeper train to the city of Xi’an, yet another historic great. Xi’an is not only the beginning and end of the ancient Silk Road, but now a thriving, sophisticated city. It also boasts many important sacred sites and ancient relics, the most famous of which is the Terracotta Army.

Your final stop is Shanghai, which you can reach on a short domestic flight from Xi’an. It feels as if eastern traditions almost crash into western culture on the banks of the East China Sea. The Bund, or waterfront, is the most well known area of the city and you will stay in a colonial hotel nearby, taking time to absorb the eclectic mix of ancient alleyways, art deco and all day, all night city culture.

dayInfo.description: Temples and Hutongs of Beijing: You’ll spend three nights soaking up the sights, sounds and smells of Beijing, an intoxicating clutter of history and modern-day ambition. Wander through the atmospheric hutongs, visit the Forbidden City and take a breather from the madness of the city at the Temple of Heavenly Peace. Top off your time in Beijing with a trip along the twisting Great Wall, one of the world’s most staggering sights. This afternoon, you’ll be collected from your hotel in Beijing and taken to the train station. You’ll take the bullet train to Xi’an which takes around 6 hours.

Terracotta Army and Drum Towers: Marvel at the soldiers of the ancient Terracotta Army and wander around the Bell Tower in Xi’an. A modern city with an imperial past, it’s an eye-opening window into Chinese culture. Drenched in history and jam-packed with fascinating places to explore. You’ll spend two nights in China’s past Imperial Capital, soaking up the atmosphere and visiting the impressive Terracotta army. Today you’ll arrange make your own way to the airport for your onward flight to the bright lights of Shanghai. Your flying time today is roughly 2.5 hours

Shanghai: Back to the Future: Explore Shanghai, crammed with skyscrapers and exploding with variety. From 19th century alleyways to swanky bars and art-deco buildings, there’s nowhere like it. With twice as many skyscrapers as Manhattan, Shanghai is a sleek modern sprawl that seems to go on forever. You will stay in a colonial style hotel close to the Bund and your time is free to explore the city at your own pace. At the end of your whirlwind adventure you'll make your own way to the airport in time to check in for your international flights home.

tourName: China 9 day tour
generalInfo: Discover the highlights of China’s ‘Golden Triangle’ on this introductory tour, visiting Beijing, Xian and Shanghai. Your journey begins in Beijing, China’s capital with a rich imperial history where you will visit the Forbidden City, enjoy the classical Chinese gardens of the Summer Palace, explore the narrow alleys of the Hutongs by bicycle, walk on the Great Wall, and learn about rituals of old at the Temple of Heaven. Continue to Xian, once known as Chang’an (Eternal Peace) and home to numerous dynasties, including the Qin dynasty whose first emperor is guarded in his afterlife by the Terracotta Warriors. After coming face-to-face with these warriors and exploring Xian’s Muslim Quarter, your trip ends in the cosmopolitan city of Shanghai, where you will see traditional China juxtaposed with the bright lights of the future.

dayInfo.description: On arrival in Beijing, you will be met at the airport by your guide and transferred to your hotel for check-in.

Start your discovery of Beijing this morning with a visit to the historic Tiananmen Square and the Forbidden City with your private guide. Surrounded by the Tiananmen Tower, Monument to the People's Heroes, Great Hall of the People, and Chairman Mao Zedong Memorial Hall, Tiananmen Square is one of the world’s largest and each day, thousands of locals come and pay respects to Chairman Mao’s statue from all over China. Continue to the imperial Forbidden City, a vast site of ancient buildings that was once off limits to all but the emperor and the imperial family.

This morning journey out of the city to visit the majestic Great Wall at Mutianyu, one of the best-preserved sections of the Wall where you will be able to admire the magnificent piece of architecture, aiding China’s defence in ancient times. Return to Beijing in the afternoon and take a tour of the scenic Summer Palace, the largest and most well-preserved royal park in Beijing, taking in its lakes, gardens, walkways and teahouses.

Spend this morning exploring the Temple of Heaven with your private guide. This Confucian-designed temple is technically an altar and stands in the middle of a leafy park. We can arrange for you to arrive early, so you can see Beijing residents performing the ancient art of Tai chi. Later you will be taken to Beijing West railway station by private transfer to catch the bullet train to Xian, home of the Terracotta Warriors, a five-and-a-half-hour journey. On arrival, you're met by a private guide and driver and transferred to your hotel.

Today you will take a full day tour to see Xian’s most famous sights. Begin with a visit to Xian's star attraction, the Terracotta Army, with your private guide. Even if you have read about these ancient models, nothing can prepare you for their sheer scale and number. Discovered in 1974 by a group of farmers digging a well, it is now one of the main tourist attractions in China and one of the most important archaeological finds of the 20th century. Return to the city and take a walk on the Ancient City Wall. Originally built during the Ming dynasty, the city wall has been restored to its former glory and you can marvel at the sheer scale of the construction as you stroll along the ramparts that provide magnificent views of the city. End the day with a visit to the Muslim Quarter, walking through the narrow lanes that feature old mud brick houses, butchers’ shops, small sesame oil factories and the Grand Mosque.

This morning, transfer by private car with your guide to Xian airport and fly to Shanghai. On arrival in Shanghai, you will be met at the airport by your guide and taken to your hotel by private car. Alternatively, you may wish to take a ride on the super-fast Maglev train into the city and continue by private transfer to your hotel. The remainder of the day is at leisure for you to soak in the atmosphere of China’s exciting modern city.

Today you will explore the vibrant city of Shanghai by bike in the morning. This shared cycling tour takes you through the French Concession quarter, with its elegant Art Deco villas, before plunging you into the backstreets and alleyways of off-the-beaten-path residential areas and the maze of narrow streets that make up Shanghai’s old town to see the daily life of local people. You’ll also see the plethora of activities that take place in one of the city’s main public parks and visit a Buddhist temple. The remainder of the day is at leisure for you to explore the city independently. We suggest visiting the Shanghai Museum. Rated among the best museums in Asia, the museum boasts a comprehensive collection of Chinese cultural artefacts and art. You may wish to visit Yu Gardens, where you'll have the chance to explore the gardens, bazaars and maze of narrow lines lined with traditional houses or take a walk along the historic Bund to admire its colonial architecture and soak up the views of the famous Pudong skyline on the opposite bank of Huangpu river. We can also arrange a leisurely boat trip along the river for a relaxing way to see old and new Shanghai instead.
Today you'll be collected form your hotel and driven to the airport for your return flight.

tourName: China and Tibet tailor made tour
generalInfo: A private 2-Week China tour including Beijing, XI'an, Shanghai and the city on the roof of the world, Lhasa. The Tibet permit is included.

dayInfo.description: Landing in Beijing, you will be met by your private guide and driver who will transfer you to your hotel. Meals: No meals Accommodation: 4 or 5 star hotel

Walking through Tian'anmen Square, and then arrive at the Forbidden City. Enjoy some Beijing cuisine for lunch. Afterward, take a short rickshaw ride in the hutongs and find out how the local people live their daily lives. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch.
Spend your morning at the Temple of Heaven. Then you'll head to the highlight: the Mutianyu section of the Great Wall. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch.
Beijing to Xi'an. Visit the Summer Palace, then Take a bullet train from Beijing to Xian. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch. Accommodation: 4 or 5 star hotel

Visit the Terracotta Army Museum. You will try to make your own terracotta warrior inside a traditional cave dwelling. After lunch, return to the city area and visit Xi'an City Wall, Walking along the ancient wall provides a good view of the city. You can also rent a bike to cycle around the wall. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch.

Visit Big Wild Goose Pagoda and Shaanxi History Museum. Meet up with a family in town. They will teach you how to make dumplings on your own. Taste the dumplings and chat with the locals to learn more about the real China as well as just sightseeing. In the late afternoon, visit the bustling Muslim Quarter, which is a paradise of local snacks. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch.

Xi'an to Lhasa. Your guide and driver will see you off at Xi'an. Catch the flight to Lhasa. The rest of the day is for you to take a rest at your hotel. With an altitude of 3,650 meters (11,975 feet), we usually suggest a free day to acclimatize to the high altitude. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch. Accommodation: 4 or 5 star hotel

Located on the hillside, Drepung Monastery is the largest Tibetan Buddhist monastery. After lunch, pay a visit to Norbulingka, Tibet's Summer Palace. As a living museum of Tibetan architecture, it serves as a city park now. You can see Tibetan families playing or having a picnic there. In the afternoon, see monks debating at Sera Monastery. Debating is a normal activity, similar to having lessons in a class. It is held on open grounds every day at 3pm, except Sundays. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch.

Visit Jokhang Temple, explore Barkhor Street including its local market, and take afternoon tea in peaceful Ani Tsangkhung Nunnery. Pilgrimage to the Potala Palace at last. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch.
After breakfast, you will be driven for about 2 hours to reach Yamdrok Lake Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch.

Lhasa to Shanghai. You will take a long flight of 5 hours from the west of Tibet to the east of Shanghai. The flight will stop over in Chengdu or Xi'an. Your Shanghai guide will be waiting for you and will transfer you to your hotel. Enjoy your free time for the rest of the day. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch. Accommodation: 4 or 5 star hotel

Visit Yu Garden, the Bund. Walk through the shikumen and meet some locals and learn about their daily lives inside their traditional houses. Finally, take the fastest elevator in the world to the observation level of Shanghai Tower (the highest building in China) and take in a panoramic view of the Bund. Meals: Breakfast and Chinese Lunch.
Your private guide and driver will see you off at the airport, assisting you with your flight check-in and luggage.

tourName: China backpacking tours
generalInfo:
Spend your time off visiting one of the largest and most exciting countries in the world. Depending on how much time you have, join either our 16 day or 25 day tour.

You will join a group of travelers all keen to see the real China. You will be have an experienced tour guide with you throughout, who can help you make the most out of your time in China!

See the amazing sites of China in a unique way. Travel by public transport and stay in hostels, chosen for their character, on this affordable tour.

Want to add this tour to one of our China teaching projects? Speak to the team!

dayInfo.description: Hong Kong - Victoria Peak
Yangshuo - Bamboo rafting down the Li River. Optional activities - kayaking, deep water soloing, mud baths, cooking class, a Cormorant fishing demonstration

Chengdu - Learn some Mandarin, meet the Pandas, Wenshu Monastery, Sichuan Province Museum and a traditional Chinese tea-house Option activities - massage with a blind physical therapist, Sichuan opera, Leshan to see the largest stone Buddha, Tibetan quarter
Xi'an - Muslim quarter, Silk Road Market, Terracotta Warriors Optional activities - Karaoke, Cycle tour around the city walls
Shaolin - Deng-Feng for Kung Fu lesson, Madarin lesson, Kung Fu demonstration by masters

Beijing - Mandarin lesson, Great Wall of China (locals only section) camping in good weather, Olympic Bird's Nest Stadium, Tienanmen Square, The Forbidden City, The Temple of Heaven Optional activities - acrobat show, try Peking Roast Duck For those on the 16 day tour, you will leave on the 15th day to travel back to Hong Kong, unless you would prefer to stay in Beijing
Moganshan - Bamboo nature reserve, cycle tour of local villages, Mogan Mountain
Shanghai - Propaganda History Museum, Ferry across Huangpu River, Nanjing Road Optional activities - Tianzifang, rooftop bar
Fujian - Night in a Tulou, walking tour of UNESCO World Heritage Site, Sample local tea Optional activities - Cycle
Macao - St Paul's, Old Fortress, Venetian Macao Resort Hotel At the end of the tour, you can travel via high speed ferry back to Hong Kong

tourName: China family holiday in Sichuan
generalInfo:
Sichuan includes some of China’s most important remaining natural habitats and has long served as a last bastion for many of China’s endangered animals, including the iconic wild giant panda. The province’s reputation as a home for wildlife, along with its beautiful alpine vistas and parks, has attracted travelers both domestic and overseas for years. Focusing on the scientific aspects of these natural wonders, Emei buddhist mountain and Leshan Grand Buddha were listed as the World Natural and Cultural heritage together by UNESCO in 1996. 

As someone who is deeply in love of and most familiar with the land, we do nothing but make your travel in Sichuan most rewarding. On this journey, we will have chance to make handcraft of porcelain and pottery, and take a boat cruise to have a face-to-face view of for Giant Buddha, hike on Qingcheng Mountain and E'mei Mountain, visit Anren Ancient Town that are being preserved culturally and architecturally as museums, you do nothing but immerse yourself in Sichuan wonders together with us.

dayInfo.description: Arrive in Chengdu: Our tour begins today. Be met the local guide at Chengdu Airport, we drive to the downtown. After lunch, we go to Wuhou Temple, a memorial temple of Zhu Geliang, a legend of wisdom in Chinese history during the Three Kingdoms period. Then we go to the Bamboo Park to see how the local people enjoy their daily life in a tea house situated among the nice bamboo woods. You can enjoy with them, like how local people do. In the evening, we will take you to enjoy a Facing Changing Show. Lunch and dinner included

Chengdu to E'mei Mountain: This morning, we will drive to experience Chinese Pottery Art. We will take you to an old kiln cave to have the greatest fun by making handcraft of porcelain and pottery. This kiln cave hide in a peaceful village, in a dragon shape standing for over hundred years since Qing Dynasty. After lunch, we drive to Leshan for Giant Buddha. The Giant Buddha locates right at the confluence of the three rivers of Minjiang, Qingyi River and Dadu River. We can take a 0.5 hour's boat cruise to have a face-to-face view of it from the center of the rivers. Either we will enter the Giant Buddha Park to get a close admire of the largest Buddha in the world. In the park, we take steep steps down to the foot of the Giant Buddha along its left side. We can take specified angle for photo shoot from the head to the foot. Followed with the Giant Buddha, we drive to E'mei. breakfast, lunch and dinner included.

E'mei Mountain: Mt. Emei is like a huge green screen standing in the southwest of the Chengdu Plain. It is the highest one among all the famous sight-seeing mountains in China. Its main peak, the Golden Summit, is 3079.3 meters (10,103 feet) above the sea level, seemingly reaching the sky. In 1996 Mt. Emei was enlisted in the world natural and cultural heritage by the UNESCO. In the morning, we will take a 40mins sightseeing bus to Wuxiangang Station, and start our walk for about an hour to Qingyin Pavilion, the most beautiful landscape of Mount Emei. On the way we may follow the stream up, passing by local villages and a manmade lake. Then keep walking for another 1 hour up to the famous Ecological Monkey Area. Among those more than 3000 species of plants and animals here, the wild monkeys are the real hosts of this magic mountain mainly because of their naughtiness and cleverness. After that we walk down back to Qingyin Pavilion and start a 1 hour hiking to Wannian Temple at the middle of the mountain. It is one of the most ancient temples on Emei Mountain. And then, we will take a 1.5hours sightseeing bus to Leidongping, and walk about 30mins to the Cable car station and take the cable car up to the golden summit. Overnight in Golden Summit Hotel. Breakfast, lunch and dinner included.

Mt Emei to Anren Ancient Town: After watching the glorious sunrise, we will take the cable car down to Leidongping, and take about 2 hours’ sightseeing bus to the foot of Mt. Emei. And then, we drive another 2.5hs to Anren Ancient Town. This town has 27 large Qing Dynasty mansions that are being preserved culturally and architecturally as museums. While there, take some time to explore these. Being only 65 kilometres from Chengdu, this ancient town offers an experience that is a bit different from others. The town itself, with black-tile roofing, zigzagging alley streets, and stone-slab walkways, has plenty for visitors to buy and eat. The shops, while selling the usual ancient town style souvenirs, do feature antiques like old dial phones, bicycles and furniture. Note that you can't buy the antique memorabilia. An old theatre hosts live shows all the time as well. Taking the old town tram, even if you don't need transportation anywhere, is worth it. It feels like a trip back in time, China style. Stay in Anren Ancient Town. Breakfast, lunch and dinner included

Anren Ancient Town to Qingcheng Mountain: Mt. Qingcheng is one of the most famous Taoist mountains in China. It is also a very attractive and intriguing scenic spot that is covered by luxuriant and verdant trees. After breakfast, we drive about 60minutes from Anren Ancient Town to Mt Qingcheng, and hike on Qingcheng Mountain. As the early residence of one of the Taoist founders and now a UNESCO World Heritage Site, Qingcheng Mountain's path is lined with temples and sanctuaries. As such, it is the perfect retreat from bustling city life and provides visitors with a profound sense of calm. Visitors spend several hours on the tranquil mountain route, enjoying the peace of the natural surroundings. Less crowded and tourist-frequented than neighboring mountains, Qingcheng Mountain's hiking path is tranquil and allows visitors to enjoy peace of mind and peace of nature in the elevated surroundings. The total hike lasts between 3 to 4 hours, and is approximately 10 to 12 kilometers long.Back to Chengdu, enjoy the face-change show. Breakfast, lunch and dinner included.

Depart Chengdu: Today in the morning we drive about 2 hours to Guanghan for the Sanxingdui Museum. It represents a totally different culture as the Zhongyuan (Orient of the Middle Kingdom) Culture. In the past, people believe that Zhongyuan is the orient of Chinese all cultures, all the ethnic groups live in the borders now are descendants of the immigrants from north China. But Sanxingdui archaeological discovery challenge the popular theory. Then we drive directly to Chengdu airport for your flight to the next destination or back home. Breakfast and lunch included.

tourName: China highlights holiday
placesVisited: Beijing, Great Wall, Xi'an, Terracotta Warriors, Yangshuo, Karst Mountains, Moon Hill, Hangzhou, Shanghai
generalInfo: Visit iconic sites and bring the fascinating history and culture of China to life. Beijing’s past spans three millennia and the scale of Tiananmen Square and the Forbidden City never fail to amaze. Leaving the grandeur behind, explore the narrow hutongs of the old town. Head out of the city and step foot on one of the best-preserved sections of the Great Wall; here, we begin to comprehend the magnitude of this construction as it snakes across the mountains to the horizon and beyond. In Xi’an, we explore the vibrant Muslim Quarter and see the Terracotta Warriors of Emperor Qin. A trip to China would not be complete without visiting Chengdu to see giant pandas. End in cosmopolitan Shanghai, with its unmistakable skyline illuminated at night.

dayInfo.description: Our adventure begins in Beijing, the capital of China and home to world-renowned landmarks such as the Forbidden City. Free arrival transfers are available for everyone arriving into either Beijing Capital Airport (PEK) or Daxing Airport (PKX). Around 6pm, say ni hao to your tour leader and fellow travellers, when we gather as a group for the first time to get to know each other and learn more about the adventures ahead. Your tour leader then ensures a big welcome by arranging a group dinner at a local restaurant. Want more time in Beijing? Secure pre-tour hotel nights through your sales representative. Accommodation: Dong Fang Hotel (or similar)

We head straight to Tiananmen Square (approximately 30 minutes by public bus/metro), one of the largest squares in the world, able to hold more than a million people. The square is named after the Tiananmen (meaning Gate of Heavenly Peace) at its north, which leads to the Forbidden City. Continuing on foot, we spend a few hours exploring the innumerable courtyards and temples of the Forbidden City. Exiting via the north gate of the complex, we walk directly to Jingshan Park and climb to the top of the hill for a different vantage point. After lunch, we have a walking tour around traditional hutongs (narrow alleys of the old town), before meandering back to the hotel. Note: Following the Covid-19 pandemic, maximum numbers of daily visitors to the Forbidden City have been significantly reduced, impacting availability of tickets. Our local team aim to secure tickets for the Forbidden City, but if unable to do so, we visit the Ancestral Temple (used during the Ming and Qing Dynasties to offer sacrifices to ancestors, and architecturally quite similar to the Forbidden City) and the Temple of Heaven instead. You will be advised at the start of the trip if this change needs to be made. Accommodation: Dong Fang Hotel (or similar)

We leave the capital and head into the countryside (approximately two hours’ drive) to visit one of the best-preserved sections of the Great Wall, at Mutianyu. It is an impressive sight, snaking across mountains and valleys into the distance. We take the shuttle bus to the ticket office; from there, it’s about a 40-minute uphill walk to the top of the Great Wall (anyone not wanting to walk can pay to take the cable car, which takes about eight minutes). We spend the next couple of hours or so walking along the top of the wall. There are some steep steps to navigate and anyone who suffers from vertigo may find it difficult. This section of the Great Wall used to serve as the northern barrier, defending the capital and the imperial tombs. The wall here stands up to 28ft (8.5m) high and 16ft (5m) wide, and there are 22 watchtowers along its 7,380ft (2,250m) stretch. Accommodation: Dong Fang Hotel (or similar)

We take a bullet train to Xi’an this morning, which takes about 4hr 30min.
